item.title: Stranger in the Shogun's City
item.description: Before reading Stanley’s book, I would have assumed that early modern Japan had hyper-low divorce rates, or perhaps even lacked a legal mechanism for divorce. Even today, Japan has a relatively low divorce rate—1.7 per thousand people, compared with 2.7 in the US and 3.2 in China—and you might figure it was even lower during the Tokugawa era. But on the contrary, divorce was actually quite common. Although every girl could expect to marry, everyone knew that marriages didn’t necessarily last.
